name: Akureyri
fun_fact: Fun fact: Akureyri, Iceland's 'Capital of the North,' sits just 60km south of the Arctic Circle at the end of Eyjafj√∂r√∞ur - Iceland's longest fjord. It's one of only two Icelandic harbors offering year-round whale watching with humpback whales visible even in winter, and you might see northern lights dancing over the fjord.

hero_dishes.name: Plokkfiskur (Fish Stew)
hero_dishes.description: Mashed fish (usually cod or haddock) mixed with potatoes, onions, butter, and b√©chamel sauce - creamy, warming comfort food
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created by Icelandic fishermen's wives to use leftover fish, plokkfiskur ('plucked fish') became national comfort food. In Akureyri's harsh Arctic winters with limited daylight, this rich, warming stew sustained fishing families. The dish shows Icelandic resourcefulness - nothing wasted, everything warming.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Traditional Icelandic restaurants in Akureyri, guesthouses, or cafes serving local cuisine

hero_dishes.name: Kj√∂ts√∫pa (Lamb Soup)
hero_dishes.description: Hearty soup with Icelandic lamb, root vegetables (potatoes, carrots, turnips), and herbs - simple, nourishing, soul-warming
hero_dishes.origin_story: Iceland's national dish uses the island's free-range lamb that grazes on wild herbs and moss, creating unique flavor. Akureyri residents eat kj√∂ts√∫pa year-round, especially after winter activities like skiing or Northern Lights hunting. Each family has their secret herb blend.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Akureyri restaurants, cafes, and the Akureyri Food Hall

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Arctic Char
hero_dishes.description: Salmon-like fish from Iceland's cold rivers and lakes, often pan-fried or grilled with butter and herbs
hero_dishes.origin_story: Arctic char thrives in Iceland's pristine glacial waters. Akureyri's location at Eyjafj√∂r√∞ur fjord provides access to incredibly fresh fish. The char has pink flesh like salmon but a more delicate flavor. Locals eat it simply prepared to taste the clean Arctic waters.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Seafood restaurants in Akureyri, especially near the harbor

hero_dishes.name: Skyr with Berries
hero_dishes.description: Thick, creamy Icelandic yogurt (technically cheese) served with wild bilberries or crowberries
hero_dishes.origin_story: Skyr dates back to Viking times - it's been made in Iceland for over 1,000 years using similar recipes. High in protein, low in fat, it sustained Icelanders through harsh winters. Akureyri locals eat it for breakfast with wild berries foraged from surrounding hills. Modern Icelanders call it yogurt; technically it's cultured cheese.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every grocery store, cafe, and breakfast buffet in Akureyri - it's everywhere

signature_drinks.name: Brenniv√≠n
signature_drinks.description: Icelandic schnapps flavored with caraway seeds - clear, strong (37.5% alcohol), nicknamed 'Black Death'
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Brenniv√≠n ('burning wine') is Iceland's signature spirit. Traditionally drunk as a shot with h√°karl (fermented shark) to mask the shark's ammonia taste, but Akureyri locals also sip it after whale-watching tours or northern lights excursions. The black label earned it the 'Black Death' nickname. It's an acquired taste - caraway-forward, medicinal, warming.

signature_drinks.name: Icelandic Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Strong, light-roast coffee - Icelanders are among world's highest per-capita coffee consumers
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: In Akureyri's long dark winters (polar nights), coffee culture is survival. Cafes serve it strong and hot, often with kleina (Icelandic twisted donuts). Locals drink it constantly - before whale watching, after skiing, during northern lights waits. Iceland imports all coffee but consumes more per person than almost any country.
